results.sentence: My father, David Johnson, was a mechanic who worked in Chicago for 35 years before retiring in 2018.
My grandmother Maria Elena Rodriguez immigrated from Mexico to California in 1965 and raised seven children on her own.
My sister Sarah graduated from Harvard Medical School in 2015 and now practices pediatrics in Seattle.
My uncle James and aunt Patricia celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary last June at their farm in Iowa.
My cousin Alex was born with cystic fibrosis in 2002 but has become an accomplished swimmer despite his condition.
My great-grandfather fought in World War II from 1942-1945 and received a Purple Heart after being wounded at Normandy.
My twin brothers, Michael and Matthew, were born on April 15, 1998, and both now work as software engineers in Austin.
My mother-in-law, Dr. Elizabeth Chang, founded a nonprofit organization in 2010 that provides medical care to underserved communities in rural Tennessee.
My son Kevin was diagnosed with autism at age 3 but has thrived since we enrolled him in a specialized education program in 2018.
My wife's parents, Robert and Janice Wilson, emigrated from Scotland in 1975 and opened a bakery in Portland that's still operating today.
My stepfather, Colonel Thomas Bradley, served in the Marine Corps for 28 years before retiring in 2005 and marrying my mother in 2007.
My daughter Emma was born on February 12, 2019, at Massachusetts General Hospital, weighing 7 pounds and 3 ounces.
My half-brother from my father's first marriage, Jonathan, is 15 years older than me and lives in Sydney, Australia with his wife and three children.
My husband's grandmother, Hiroko Tanaka, survived the Hiroshima bombing in 1945 when she was just 8 years old and later moved to Hawaii in 1960.
My niece, Olivia Chen Williams, was adopted from China in 2012 when she was 14 months old and has become an amazing pianist.
Both my parents grew up in Buffalo, New York, met at Syracuse University in 1985, and got married in 1990 after graduating with degrees in engineering.
My brother-in-law served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Kenya from 2008 to 2010 before returning to complete his PhD in Anthropology at UCLA.
My youngest son, Tyler, was diagnosed with leukemia when he was 6 years old in 2017, underwent treatment for two years, and has been in remission since 2019.
My great-aunt Martha lived to be 104 years old, was born during World War I in 1917, and witnessed everything from the Great Depression to the smartphone era before passing away in 2021.

My grandfather on my mother's side, Joseph O'Malley, worked as a coal miner in Pennsylvania for 42 years starting in 1952, raised five children with my grandmother Eleanor, and passed away from black lung disease in 2003.
